0.user_question: Pam and Fred went to a carnival. Pam rode the roller coaster 9401149 times while Fred rode it 4 times. After that, each of them decided to ride the luge 9401149 times. If each ride cost 6 tickets, how many tickets did they use that day?

ost_step.1: Calculate the number of rides for both Pam and Fred on the roller coaster before deciding about the luges: (9401149 + 4) * 2 people = 18802298 rides on the roller coaster.
ost_step.2: Each ride costs 6 tickets, so calculate this amount first: 18802298 rides * 6 tickets/ride = 112813788 tickets spent on roller coasters.
ost_step.3: Next, find out the combined ticket usage from all three actions including their decision to go on the luge as well: Combine initial action result [calculated above] plus subsequent activity which was equal since they agreed to ride together equals doubled original count minus one because we counted only once when counting per person but not twice here. This means multiplying our previous sum by two then subtracting one extra operation at end due to no need repeated calculation during simultaneous execution; hence overall expenditure would increase by just adding half value instead repeating whole thing again fully separately thus resulting equation becomes ((initial_total*2)-(original_count)*half). In other words, ((18802298 rides * 6 tickets)+((18802298+4)/2))*.5=<<=(112813788+940115)=112814723>>112814723tickets used throughout entire experience combining individual enjoyment via varied attractions shared mutually without overlap duplication errors impacting accurate tally adjustments postulated prior analysis yield net aggregate figure accordingly provided scenario conditions align respectively satisfying required output specifications

But since this problem only mentions about just visiting once without any other conditions such as waiting time before another turn comes around… let us assume everyone spent Z ticket(s).
